name: Bjargtangar - Europe's Westernmost Lighthouse
description: Bjargtangar lighthouse occupies Europe's westernmost point at Látrabjarg Peninsula tip (excluding Atlantic island possessions like Azores) where geographic extremity creates symbolic significance as final continental landfall before vast Atlantic expanse separating Europe from North America—location atop towering bird cliffs ranging 14 kilometers length and reaching 440 meters height positions lighthouse amid Europe's largest seabird colony where millions of puffins, northern gannets, guillemots, and razorbills create cacophonous spectacle during breeding season transforming stark landscape into vibrant ecosystem. The August 12, 2026 total solar eclipse viewing opportunity positions Bjargtangar as premium observation location where eclipse totality duration extends longer at western extremity than anywhere else in Iceland, generating anticipated visitor surge testing remote Westfjords infrastructure as astronomy enthusiasts, photographers, and casual tourists converge on normally quiet peninsula seeking rare astronomical alignment—local authorities planning traffic management including potential road closures and mandatory bus shuttles reflect concerns that narrow dangerous roads cannot safely accommodate unrestricted vehicle influx during special event. The surrounding Látrabjarg cliffs' cultural significance extends beyond natural beauty as historical rescue site where local residents descended treacherous cliff faces saving British trawler crew shipwrecked during violent storm.

opening_hours.north_america_facing: Vast ocean separates from next continent
opening_hours.latrabjarg_cliffs: 14 km long, up to 440 meters high

opening_hours.totality_duration: Longest in Iceland at western extremity
